5

The Secretary does not dispute that it has no remedy against Gorman under Sec. 1132(a)(2) because Gorman is not a fiduciary

6

The Secretary does argue that one of the enforcement provisions which imposes civil penalties for participation in a fiduciary breach, 29 U.S.C. Sec. 1132(l ), indicates that Congress intended Sec. 1132(a)(5) to authorize remedies against nonfiduciaries like Gorman. We reject this argument below, see infra pages 34-35. We note here, however, that Sec. 1132(l ) is an enforcement provision and not a substantive provision; not even the Secretary claims that the provision itself creates a substantive duty not otherwise provided for in the statute. Section 1132(l ) was added to ERISA in 1989, see Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1989, Pub.L. No. 101-239, Sec. 2101, 103 Stat. 2123. Instead of extending the substantive reach of ERISA, Sec. 1132(l ) explicitly based its penalty on amounts already recoverable under existing provisions of the statute. 29 U.S.C. Sec. 1132(l )(2)(B)

7

The fact that Sec. 1106 imposes the duty to refrain from prohibited transactions on fiduciaries and not on the parties in interest is irrelevant for our purposes because Sec. 1132(a)(5) reaches "acts or practices" that violate ERISA and prohibited transactions violate Sec. 1106. Although fiduciary breaches also violate ERISA, nonfiduciaries cannot, by definition, engage in the act or practice of breaching a fiduciary duty. Nonfiduciaries, can, however, engage in the act or practice of transacting with an ERISA plan

8

The Secretary makes no allegation that Gorman received unreasonable compensation for his services. If such had been the case, the Secretary might have stated a cause of action based on Gorman's engagement in a prohibited transaction, 29 U.S.C. Sec. 1106, but not for participation in a fiduciary breach

9

29 U.S.C. Sec. 1132(l ) provides in relevant part:

(1) In the case of--

(A) any breach of fiduciary responsibility under (or other violation of) part 4 by a fiduciary, or

(B) any knowing participation in such a breach or violation by any other person,

the Secretary shall assess a civil penalty against such fiduciary or other person in an amount equal to 20 percent of the applicable recovery amount.

(2) For purposes of paragraph (1), the term "applicable recovery amount" means any amount which is recovered from a fiduciary or other person with respect to a breach or violation described in paragraph (1)--

(A) pursuant to any settlement agreement with the Secretary, or

(B) ordered by a court to be paid by such fiduciary or other person to a plan or its participants and beneficiaries in a judicial proceeding instituted by the Secretary under subsection (a)(2) or (a)(5) of this section.

Under paragraph (3) of Sec. 1132(l ), the Secretary may waive or reduce this penalty if he believes that "the fiduciary or other person will [otherwise] not be able to restore all losses to the plan without severe financial hardship." 29 U.S.C. Sec. 1132(l )(3)(B).

10

The Secretary takes issue with Justice Scalia's proposal that "any other person" in Sec. 1132(l )(1)(B) could refer to cofiduciaries. According to the Secretary, cofiduciary liability, established under 29 U.S.C. Sec. 1105, clearly falls under Sec. 1132(l )(1)(A) and not Sec. 1132(l )(1)(B). We need not resolve this dispute and therefore do not

11

We recognize that prohibited transactions are also covered by a separate civil penalty provision, 29 U.S.C. Sec. 1132(i), but that does not necessarily mean civil penalties for prohibited transactions cannot be obtained under Sec. 1132(l ) as well. The penalty under Sec. 1132(i) is completely discretionary and adjusted according to whether the prohibited transaction was corrected or not. The penalty under Sec. 1132(l ), however, is mandatory and contains special procedures for a general waiver. Thus, the two provisions appear to serve distinct and coextensive purposes: one is tailored specifically to redress individual transactions while the other is designed to penalize conduct more generally
